content: We need aircraft carriers to effectively field a high performance jet in that region. China does not. We have our fleet spread out all over the world. China does not. We have to transit choke points. China has to close them. We are far from the battlespace. China is close. The real crux of all of this is that we are vulnerable (as pertains to this conversation), and China is not. They do not want a world-spanning super-navy to challenge ours; rather, they want a world class regional navy that can stop ours from achieving our objectives in a small defined area. They are doing a damned good job of that - in fact, my guess is that the only thing preventing them from temporary parity/superiority is their training and doctrine. Refusal to see China as an emerging naval power that can threaten our regional superiority is wishful thinking.

content: Canuck_Centaur: If everything you read on my blog you have already seen elsewhere, why do you read my blog? You are wrong again with respect to the Chinese Navy rehabilitating the unfinished Russian carrier VARYAG. She has been sitting at the same pier in Dalian for several years--she has been painted but no work has been done on her. The carrier is readily visible from a nearby commercial hotel. Why would the Chinese Navy go to the expense of rehabilitating and sending to sea a carrier that was designed more than 40 years ago--and has never had her engines, controls, radars, and many other important features installed. The cost of producing and installing those compoients would probably be more than building a new carrier as those suppliers are mostly no longer in business (in Russia and the Ukraine), and if they are they no longer produce suitable systems for that particular design. Rather, the Chinese Navy has used the VARYAG as a schoolroom for naval architects interested in carrier design. As for the Chinese now building two 50-60,000 ton carriers--wrong again. Satellite photography (some of which is commercially available) of the two or three yards in China that could construct such ships show no activity that would indicate carrier programs are underway; similarly, the firms that could produce such items as aircraft elevators for carriers show no such projects on their order books. It is difficult to build a carrier in secret. Could you share with us some of the "sources" that you quote? Yes, China will undoubtedly build aircraft carriers in the future. But reports that they are now building them--and some "unnamed sources" tell of a 100,000-ton nuclear ship being constructed--are premature. Norman

With respect, Norman, A new shipyard capable of handling ships of this size, in excess of 50,000 tons displacement and 1,000 feet in length, looks to have been built on an island off Shanghai. Satellite imagery shows that there is much activity there but no keel has been laid although it seems preparations are being made to do just that. China has managed to keep a high level of secrecy building submarines and there is no reason to think that they cant pull off major component construction in a similar manner. We can agree that just being able to build an aircraft carrier in no way comes close to being able to effectively operate one well enough to be a credible threat to the USN but by the next decade they will be taking great pains to attempt to get into a combat capable mode. 2015 may be a bit premature but they will get it done. Also, I can confirm that nothing special is going on with the Varyag except with the possible name change but that doesnt mean anything either. What is interesting is that the J-11BS has been seen at CFTE last week which is the second domestically produced Flanker clone which is supposed to be a heavy, multi-role strike aircraft like the F-15E and supposedly the "naval flanker" variant J-11BJ is expected by 2010 so why would they be investing in Naval aircraft if they didnt plan on having an aircraft carrier by 2015 for the aircraft to be serial produced and ready by then? Additionally, if the stepped up production of the Yuan class sub is any indication(already 3rd boat nearing completion in less than 4 years)the Chinese may be able to pull off an ambitious carrier project in a similar speedy manner as well. I still wouldnt rule out using the Varyag as a testing/training ship.

content: China's navy appears to be constructed and oriented on the soth east asian rim basin...they definitely want to be a regional naval power, especially in regards to other nations competing for nautral resources in the region. Alternatively, China does want to keep Tiwan in its sights, however with U.S. naval presence in the region, military atagonism towards Tiwan can be checked. The real issue is "anticipating" what China's future political and military objectives will be over the horizon. For example: history has shown the build up of the Japanese navy in the 1890's (during the first Sino-Japanese War for control of Korea), to war with the Russians in 1903, and eventually to the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. We need to understand what China's political, economic, and military priorities are in order to understand HOW they will grow their military!! A comprehensive assessment will lay out the framework from which to predict future hostilities!!! In the meantime we need to maintain our engagement with their military and continue to conduct joint exercises to continue to assess what their capabilities are.

content: America's costly naval philosophy was rooted in enforcing influence off its two (three?) oceanic coasts. This has been extended futher afield from time to time in defense of American interests. To such an extent that, to-day, Amercia maintains fleets in most of the worlds' oceans and well-trafficked seas. China has no such defense needs, she has no political interests abroad in need of protection. 90 percent of the resources she needs are located in Asia. What's the need to waste resources in a naval race with America? They realise there is no need for two 'world cops', just the necessity of defending against another police action. China may be a 'paper tiger', but they've proven to be far from stupid - why waste steel when they get what they want through influence? This message has been edited. content: All: Much, much easier to build submarines "in secret"--under cover, etc. Not possible to build a carrier "indoors," not even in the giant covered building ways at Sverdovinsk and Komsomolsk, which Stalin had erected to build battleships side-by-side. Again, China does want carriers and will undoubtedly build some in the future. But there are ample classified and open source indications that demonstrate conclusively that such a construction effort has not yet begun. Again, for a decade there have been reports that the VARYAG is "being completed" by China, yet absolutely no work on the ship has been observed (other than a decent paint job). For example, to install engines would require cutting upon the flight deck! The Chinese "elevator companies" that could build flight-deck lifts for future carriers are well known in the West, work with Western companies, and there would be indications if such work were being undertaken. Rather, expect to see Chinese observers aboard the new, Russian-buiult carrier when she becomes operational. Norman Norman

content: Canuck_Centaur: If everything you read on my blog you have already seen elsewhere, why do you read my blog? You are wrong again with respect to the Chinese Navy rehabilitating the unfinished Russian carrier VARYAG. She has been sitting at the same pier in Dalian for several years--she has been painted but no work has been done on her. The carrier is readily visible from a nearby commercial hotel. Why would the Chinese Navy go to the expense of rehabilitating and sending to sea a carrier that was designed more than 40 years ago--and has never had her engines, controls, radars, and many other important features installed. The cost of producing and installing those compoients would probably be more than building a new carrier as those suppliers are mostly no longer in business (in Russia and the Ukraine), and if they are they no longer produce suitable systems for that particular design. Rather, the Chinese Navy has used the VARYAG as a schoolroom for naval architects interested in carrier design. As for the Chinese now building two 50-60,000 ton carriers--wrong again. Satellite photography (some of which is commercially available) of the two or three yards in China that could construct such ships show no activity that would indicate carrier programs are underway; similarly, the firms that could produce such items as aircraft elevators for carriers show no such projects on their order books. It is difficult to build a carrier in secret. Could you share with us some of the "sources" that you quote? Yes, China will undoubtedly build aircraft carriers in the future. But reports that they are now building them--and some "unnamed sources" tell of a 100,000-ton nuclear ship being constructed--are premature. Norman

With respect, Norman, A new shipyard capable of handling ships of this size, in excess of 50,000 tons displacement and 1,000 feet in length, looks to have been built on an island off Shanghai. Satellite imagery shows that there is much activity there but no keel has been laid although it seems preparations are being made to do just that. China has managed to keep a high level of secrecy building submarines and there is no reason to think that they cant pull off major component construction in a similar manner. We can agree that just being able to build an aircraft carrier in no way comes close to being able to effectively operate one well enough to be a credible threat to the USN but by the next decade they will be taking great pains to attempt to get into a combat capable mode. 2015 may be a bit premature but they will get it done. Also, I can confirm that nothing special is going on with the Varyag except with the possible name change but that doesnt mean anything either. What is interesting is that the J-11BS has been seen at CFTE last week which is the second domestically produced Flanker clone which is supposed to be a heavy, multi-role strike aircraft like the F-15E and supposedly the "naval flanker" variant J-11BJ is expected by 2010 so why would they be investing in Naval aircraft if they didnt plan on having an aircraft carrier by 2015 for the aircraft to be serial produced and ready by then? Additionally, if the stepped up production of the Yuan class sub is any indication(already 3rd boat nearing completion in less than 4 years)the Chinese may be able to pull off an ambitious carrier project in a similar speedy manner as well. I still wouldnt rule out using the Varyag as a testing/training ship.

content: China's navy appears to be constructed and oriented on the soth east asian rim basin...they definitely want to be a regional naval power, especially in regards to other nations competing for nautral resources in the region. Alternatively, China does want to keep Tiwan in its sights, however with U.S. naval presence in the region, military atagonism towards Tiwan can be checked. The real issue is "anticipating" what China's future political and military objectives will be over the horizon. For example: history has shown the build up of the Japanese navy in the 1890's (during the first Sino-Japanese War for control of Korea), to war with the Russians in 1903, and eventually to the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. We need to understand what China's political, economic, and military priorities are in order to understand HOW they will grow their military!! A comprehensive assessment will lay out the framework from which to predict future hostilities!!! In the meantime we need to maintain our engagement with their military and continue to conduct joint exercises to continue to assess what their capabilities are.

content: America's costly naval philosophy was rooted in enforcing influence off its two (three?) oceanic coasts. This has been extended futher afield from time to time in defense of American interests. To such an extent that, to-day, Amercia maintains fleets in most of the worlds' oceans and well-trafficked seas. content: All: Much, much easier to build submarines "in secret"--under cover, etc. Not possible to build a carrier "indoors," not even in the giant covered building ways at Sverdovinsk and Komsomolsk, which Stalin had erected to build battleships side-by-side. Rather, expect to see Chinese observers aboard the new, Russian-buiult carrier when she becomes operational. Norman Norman

content: Interesting as I read this story history comes back to haunt me. Why does Dec 07, 1941 come into my memory? The USA scoffed at the Japanese Navy and their ability to successfully reach the assets of the USA, meaning Pearl Harbor. We were remiss once, shame on us, remiss twice, we will be history as we know it today.
